reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars surf — sand — sky
reviews.reviewText: This is a great read,I’m not sure that is even possible to imagine thatThe actual war was going on and all these individuals were carrying on the way they were..War always sucks, too many men,women and children meet their untimely end.However the unrelenting pursuit of good verse’s evil or strong over the weak will always beThe deciding factor..Remember,keep your head down and your feet moving..REMEMBER it’s a story,only a book

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars The English do have a way of explaining
reviews.reviewText: A very detailed story line involving British, Italian, German, American and several different Arab personnel. This along wit a variety of military ranks and civilians develop into a good story and read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2016
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars ... bias of the author being of the group of brilliant and all others being middling
reviews.reviewText: Interesting book with the classic bias of the author being of the group of brilliant and all others being middling. Perhaps written for a veterans group of the Desert Air Force as significant undefined slang, rumor reports and long lists of Group numbers without other significance.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Really enjoyed this book. Richard sure knows how to write a story. Great characters great plot what more do you need really? Looking forward to the next.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A good read
reviews.reviewText: An exciting plot and interesting characters. Descriptions of the North African theater are very invoking. I did enjoy the read, though the finale did seem a little rushed with some points skipped over. But overall, I would recommend for a Military thriller.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2021
reviews.reviewText: Precise, researched account of the R.A.F. In the North African and Italian campaigns. Many harrowing stories of extraordinary bravery and self-sacrifice.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Interesting WW2 story.
reviews.reviewText: Well, this is the first book by Bickers that I have read and I enjoyed it. There were a few British words that were not in Wikipedia and still don’t know the meaning but it didn’t get in the way of a good story.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2015
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars It would have been better with more detail but it is good
reviews.reviewText: I rate it this high for several reasons. Bickers is in his element with this book. Few historical books covered this part of the ware. It would have been better with more detail but it is good. It starts from the beginning in 1940 to 1945.I would like him to do the same with India and Burma versus the Japanese.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 9, 2022
reviews.reviewText: Very well researched and written history of the allied effort without being full of confusing statistics. An excellent account for those with an interest in WW2.

This brought back very young memories of stories my Dad relayed to me of WWll. My memories were never too complete as I was born in 1937 but grew up with the war as it took off. Richard: you are an amazing historian!!
I had no idea so many planes were used in the desert war a great story

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 5, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: Good introduction with lots of flavour.
reviews.reviewText: A short but entertaining narrative of the Desert Air Force from its beginnings in Egypt up to its end in Italy in 1945. This comprises a happy mix of narrative history mixed with eyewitness accounts and amusing anecdotes to illustrate battlefield experiences and everyday life in the Desert Air Force. The author has a very readable style that is very reminiscent of immediate post war memories and histories. This conveys a strong impression that he was a contemporary of the events he is describing and may well explain the decidedly non PC anecdotes and comments that appear from time to time.I found this a good introduction to the subject, I finished it feeling that I had a good basic understanding of both the major events and the kind of life experienced by members of the DAF at this time. Readers wishing for a more detailed focus and critical analysis may want to look at the works by Brian Cull and Christopher Shores, but for an good informative and entertaining overview you could do much worse than this.
